Juliette Garms
Project Manager Education, World Press Photo Foundation
Mar 8

Meet the Masterclass East Africa: Esther¬†Mbabazi

We asked each of the 11 participants of the satellite Masterclass East Africa six questions. Today, we‚Äôre talking with Ugandan photographer Esther¬†Mbabazi.

What was your first encounter with documentary photography?

My dad used to take photos. He had a film camera, so I grew up with rolls of film around me. So when I was in high school, I knew I wanted to tell stories. I tried writing, but it still didn‚Äôt feel like the right medium. In 2014, I met Kibuuka Mukisa Oscar, a young photographer from Uganda, and his work inspired me. I reached out to him and he taught me. At the beginning I was doing hip-hop events, but I still felt the need to tell stories. I wanted to share people‚Äôs lives with other people and create work that fosters emotions. I have always been curious about people and situations. My first story was in 2015. We had a storytelling workshop with the Uganda Press Photo Award. I did a story about village education. That was my first complete story.

Can you tell us about the photo story you made for the masterclass?

I did a project about traditional birth attendants and the health center facilities. I wanted to know how they operate and why. Why are they still out there when the government makes them illegal? Why do people go to them? So I reached out to them. I found out that they are very scared of being caught. They will tell you that they are in progress, but not yet practicing. So it was quite hard. I did manage to get some photos. I also went to the modern facilities‚Äîthat wasn‚Äôt in my plan, but the other facilities wouldn‚Äôt open up fast enough. I hope that after the masterclass I can go back and finish the story the way I wanted to. I like the project because I had other ideas regarding the themes, but I really felt I need to tell their story.

I am born and raised in Kampala, and I didn‚Äôt know that women were giving birth up in the mountains in their homes. They don‚Äôt have access to hospitals. I went to this woman who gave birth by herself. She went down the hill to the health center because she was bleeding too much. She was an emergency case. People don‚Äôt know enough about it, so I was drawn to it.

What is the most helpful thing you‚Äôve taken away from the masterclass?

I found it overall very valuable. For example, Julien Jourdes‚Äô session (founder of Blink) about pitching really helped me a lot. I am doing documentary photography and I love it, but I don‚Äôt earn money from it yet. I want to. I don‚Äôt want to do fashion. After the masterclass, I believe that I can do it. I just have to be persistent and go to the right people.

I was glad to have Thomas Mukoya among the masters. He works in Kenya for Reuters and now, after meeting him, what he does seems achievable. I already knew him, but here he was really sharing and taking the time to talk to us. I realized that the most important thing is to have good work, then it will go by itself. We also had a session with Neo and afterwards I just felt like, I can do this. She just has that passion and drive, and that talk was really needed.

What part of the job do you struggle¬†with?

Well, I still feel that I don‚Äôt belong fully to the photojournalism and documentary photography scene. I don‚Äôt yet know where to take the work. You do a project for a workshop, and everyone is like, ‚ÄúYes, it‚Äôs great,‚Äù but then what? I don‚Äôt know where to take the work. After sharing your story, you need money to continue and do more work. I want to sell it. I am doing paid work in order to do my personal projects at the same time. I need to know the right platforms. It feels like I‚Äôm getting there, but I‚Äôm impatient to show my stories. I appreciate opportunities like this masterclass.

Do you use social media professionally?

I have Instagram. It‚Äôs going well and I have many followers already. I also have a blog where I put pictures. I struggle with words, though, because I feel that the photos are enough. From the workshop, I realized that I need to write more about my images.

How do you see your career progressing?

I really want to be able to pitch my work effectively, and for that I need to build my self-confidence and my pitching skills. I am hoping that I will be able to build on my presentation and confidence when talking to editors because sometimes I feel so intimidated.

I once met this photographer who works for international media, but I did not dare to reach out to him. I want to change that. I want to be published in international media. I‚Äôve been published in Uganda newspapers, but I was not paid well enough. I felt like they didn‚Äôt value my work. That‚Äôs why Julien‚Äôs sessions were really useful. I now feel ready to contact different newspapers because I know what to tell them.

Esther was one of 12 participants selected for the 2016 Masterclass East Africa, the second in the World Press Photo Foundation‚Äôs series of satellite masterclasses based on the formula of the annual Joop Swart Masterclass for the world‚Äôs most talented upcoming visual journalists.
